docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: This user guide will explain how to use DaVinci Resolve to edit videos. DaVinci Resolve is a powerful professional video editing program, and in this guide, we'll show you how to set up your project, import footage, edit your footage, and export your footage. Our goal is to explain the basic steps of editing video footage and introduce you to the basic features that DaVinci Resolve offers.

docs.title: Who is this guide for?
docs.text: This guide is designed for beginners who are new to DaVinci Resolve or video editing in general. Whether you're a content creator, a student, or someone looking to explore professional video editing, this guide will help you get started with the basics of DaVinci Resolve.

docs.title: Hardware
docs.text:
• A computer with a multi-core processor (Intel or AMD)
  • Minimum 16GB of RAM (32GB or more recommended for 4K or higher resolution projects)
  • A dedicated GPU with at least 2GB of VRAM (4GB or more recommended for better performance)
  • Sufficient storage space for your project files and media

docs.title: Software
docs.text:
• DaVinci Resolve 18+ (Free or Studio)
  • Windows 10 or later

docs.title: Basic Knowledge
docs.text:
• Familiarity with your computer's operating system
  • Basic understanding of video formats and file management

docs.title: Media Preparation
docs.text: • Have your video footage, audio files, and any other media ready for import

docs.title: Outcome
docs.text: After completing this guide, you’ll be able to:

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
• Create and configure new projects
  • Set project resolution and frame rate

docs.title: Editing Basics
docs.text:
• Import and organize media
  • Cut, trim, and arrange clips
  • Add transitions/titles

docs.title: Export
docs.text: • Render projects for YouTube, social media, etc.

docs.title: Typographical Conventions
docs.text:
1. When navigating menus in DaVinci Resolve, we'll use italics to tell you what to click on. For example, here's how we would tell you to save your project in DaVinci Resolve:

    File -> Save Project

  2. We'll use bold text to show hotkeys in case you prefer using hotkeys instead of menus. For example, you can press Cntrl and S at the same time to save your project. Here's how we would tell you to save your project using a hotkey:

    Ctrl + S

    Please know that hotkeys are completely optional.

  3. When interacting with DaVinci Resolve's graphial user interface (GUI), we might give you a helpful GIF that shows you what to do. For example, here is a GIF that shows you how to add imported footage to your timeline so you can begin editing the footage.

  4. We'll use special info blocks to give you extra information, inform you when a task is done, or warn you before you make an irreversible action. Here's what each of those info blocks look like.

    Info

    This block will give you helpful information.

    Success

    This block will tell you that you've completed a step.

    Warning

    This block will warn you about committing an irreversible action.

Warning

  1. DaVinci Resolve requires significant computing power to run, so we recommend closing all programs that you aren't currently using. This will help you avoid crashing.
  2. Always remember to save your work before exiting DaVinci Resolve. You can do this by going to File -> Save or by pressing Cntrl + S.
  3. This guide will not explain any tools in the Fusion, Colour, or Audio pages. If you need to use these pages, you'll need to find a different user guide.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: DaVinci Resolve allows you to enhance your video clips with visual and audio effects. These effects can adjust colors, create motion, or apply stylized filters. This section will guide you through accessing the effects library, applying them to your clips, customizing their settings, and previewing the final result before exporting.

docs.title: Navigate to the Edit Page
docs.text: 1. Switch to the Edit page using the bottom navigation panel

docs.title: Access the Toolbox
docs.text:
1. Locate the bottom-left panel

  2. Click on the Toolbox tab

docs.title: Select Effects
docs.text: 1. Click on the Effects tab

docs.title: Choose an Effect
docs.text:
1. Browse the available effects
  2. Hover over options to see previews

  3. Select your desired effect

docs.title: Apply the Effect
docs.text: 1. Click and drag your chosen effect onto a clip

docs.title: Customize the Effect
docs.text:
1. Select the clip with applied effect
  2. Open the Effects panel
  3. Adjust parameters:

    • Custom settings specific to the effect

docs.title: Preview the Result
docs.text: 1. Play the clip in the Preview window

docs.title: Refine as Needed
docs.text:
1. Repeat adjustments as needed
  2. Try different effects if unsatisfied

Success

You have successfully added effects to your video! You can move on to the next section.

docs.title: Glossary
docs.text: Term Definition Timeline The workspace where video and audio clips are arranged and edited. Cut Page DaVinci Resolve's dedicated interface for fast trimming and cutting. Render Process of exporting the final video file from your edited project. Transition Visual effects between clips (e.g., fade, wipe) to smooth scene changes. Effects Modifications applied to clips (color grading, blurs, distortions). Blade Cut Tool to split clips at specific points on the timeline. Fusion DaVinci Resolve's advanced compositing and motion graphics workspace. Proxy Mode Uses lower-resolution copies of media for smoother editing performance.

docs.title: Rendering Your Project in DaVinci Resolve
Overview
docs.text: Rendering is the final step where DaVinci Resolve processes your edited timeline into a finished video file. This converts all your edits, effects, and transitions into a single playable video that you can share or upload.

docs.title: Navigate to the Deliver Page
docs.text: 1. Switch to the Deliver page using the bottom navigation panel

docs.title: Set Project Name and Destination
docs.text:
1. In the Render Settings panel:

    • Enter your project name
    • Click Browse to choose save location

  2. Select a destination folder with sufficient storage space

docs.title: Configure Render Settings
docs.text:
1. Adjust settings manually:

    • Format (QuickTime, MP4, etc.)
    • Codec (H.264, DNxHR, etc.)
    • Resolution and frame rate

    • Quality settings

  2. OR select from presets:

    • YouTube/Vimeo presets
    • Broadcast standards

    • Custom saved presets

docs.title: Start the Render Process
docs.text:
1. Verify settings in the render queue

  2. Click Add to Render Queue

  3. Click Render All to begin

docs.title: Monitor the Render
docs.text:
1. Watch the progress bar
  2. Check estimated time remaining
  3. View completed file size estimation

Important Notes

  • Do not close DaVinci Resolve during rendering
  • Avoid running other hardware-intensive software
  • Ensure adequate power supply (for laptops)
  • Monitor storage space during long renders

docs.title: Locate Your Rendered File
docs.text:
1. After completion, navigate to your chosen destination

  2. Play the video to verify quality

Success

You have successfully rendered to your video! You can move on to the next section.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This section will help you set up your project so you can begin editing. We’ll cover creating a new project, importing footage, and saving your project.

docs.title: Create a new project
docs.text:
1. Open DaVinci Resolve. It will automatically launch the project manager
  2. Press “new project” to create a new project
  3. Enter the name of your project

docs.title: Import video footage
docs.text:
1. Go to File->Import->Media and import the video files you want to edit. Alternatively, you can press Cntrl + I

Info

After importing the first video file, DaVinci Resolve might ask you to change your project framerate. Select Change and continue.

Warning

You may get an error saying DaVinci Resolve can't read the file you imported. This is because your laptop can't read all video files. We recommend using .mp4 video files to avoid this.

docs.title: Save your project
docs.text:
1. Go to File->Save Project and save your project. Alternatively, you can press Cntrl + S

Info

DaVinci Resolve should automatically save your work. However, we encourage you to manually save after major steps so that your work isn't lost if DaVinci Resolve crashes.

Success

You have successfully set up your project! You can move on to the next section.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: DaVinci Resolve stores all of the video clips in a timeline. This timeline is how you organize your clips in your video, and will be rendered to produce the final result. This section will help you add tracks to your timeline, add your footage to the corresponding timelines, cut the footage if needed, and preview the final video in the Preview window.

docs.title: Add tracks to your timeline
docs.text:
The timeline is organized into seperate tracks. For each clip that will appear simultaneously in your final video, you will need to add a track for it. For example, if you plan to have a video, a background, and audio file all playing at the same time, then you will need two video tracks and one audio track. However, if you only plan to have one video clip and one audio clip playing at the same, then you only need one video and one audio track. These steps will help you add additonal tracks.

Info

Don't know how many video and audio tracks you need? Just make sure there is one video track and one audio track. You can always add more later.

  1. Navigate to Edit page
  2. See if there are already enough tracks. DaVinci Resolve might already added an audio track and video track by default. The following gif shows you where the tracks would appear if they were automatically added.
  3. Right-click on the Tools tab and select Add Tracks
  4. Enter the number of additional Audio and Video Tracks you need and press Add Tracks. The following gif shows what adding two more video and audio tracks would look like, but your amount will be different.

Info

Added too many tracks? You can always right click on a track and select Delete.

docs.title: Add footage to your timeline
docs.text:
1. Select Snap Mode. This will help your videos snap together, ensuring that there is no gap in your timeline. This should be enabled by default.
  2. Select Link Mode. This will ensure that as you move your video, the corresponding audio moves too. This should be enabled by default.
  3. Drag and drop each video file into the correct position on the correct track. Remember, footage will be played in the order that it appears on the track, so place your footage in the order it should appear
  4. Ensure the first clip is at the start of the timeline. Otherwise, there will be a gap at the start of the video where there is just a black screen.
  5. Ensure there are no gaps between clips. Otherwise, there will be gaps in the final video where there is just a black screen.

docs.title: Cut your footage
docs.text:
For each video clip, you may want to cut some part of it out. These steps will show you how to cut a video clip. Please use these steps as needed.

  1. Select Blade Edit Mode. By default, you should be using Select Mode.
  2. Click on the start and end of the section in the footage you would like to cut
  3. Select Select Mode
  4. Right click on the footage you would like to cut and select Delete.

Info

If you want to undo this delete, or any action in general, simply press Cntrl + Z or go to Edit->Undo.

  1. Adjust the timeline as needed.

docs.title: Preview your video
docs.text:
1. Move the playhead bar to where you would like the preview to start.
  2. Press the play button to see the preview

Info

The preview video might lag when playing. This is because DaVinci Resolve is rendering the video in real time. The final video will play properly after rendering.

Success

You have successfully assembled your project timeline! You can move on the next section.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
More complex editing options, like cropping, zooming in, or changing the audio volume, can be accessed in the Transform or Crop Tab in the Edit page. This section will give you optional steps for different editing options you can apply to your footage. Please use these steps as needed.

Info

For each edit you do, make sure to select the clip in your timeline that you want to edit.

docs.title: Change the footage's position on the screen
docs.text: 1. Navigate to the Transform Tab and enter the new x and y positions for the footage

docs.title: Zoom in/Zoom out
docs.text: 1. Navigate to the Transform Tab and enter the new zoom value

docs.title: Rotate footage
docs.text: 1. Navigate to the Transform Tab and either enter the new rotation angle or use the slider

docs.title: Flip footage
docs.text: 1. Navigate to the Transform Tab and flip the image horizontally, vertically, or both

docs.title: Crop Footage
docs.text:
1. Navigate to the Crop Tab
  2. Find the Crop option you’d like to use. You can Crop the top, left, right, or bottom and enter the new crop value

docs.title: Adjust Opacity
docs.text: 1. Navigate to the Composite Tab and either enter the new opacity value or use the slider.

docs.title: Adjust Volume
docs.text:
1. Navigate to the Audio Tab and enter the new volume value

Success

You have successfully used the transform tab to edit your video! You can move on to the next section.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Transitions help smoothly connect clips in your timeline, creating professional flow between scenes. DaVinci Resolve offers video transitions (like fades, wipes, and dissolves) and audio transitions (like crossfades) to polish your project.

docs.title: Navigate to the Edit Page
docs.text: 1. Switch to the Edit page using the bottom navigation panel

docs.title: Access the Toolbox
docs.text:
1. Locate the bottom-left panel

  2. Click on the Toolbox tab

docs.title: Select Transition Type
docs.text:
1. From the dropdown menu, choose:

    • Video Transitions for visual effects

    • Audio Transitions for sound crossfades

docs.title: Choose a Transition
docs.text:
1. Browse the available transitions
  2. Hover over options to see previews

  3. Select your desired transition

docs.title: Apply the Transition
docs.text:
1. Click and drag the transition to your timeline:
    • Between clips: For standard transitions

    • Start/end of clip: For fade-in/out effects

docs.title: Adjust Transition Settings
docs.text:
1. Click on the transition in the timeline
  2. Modify parameters:
    • Duration
    • Alignment

    • Custom settings

docs.title: Preview the Transition
docs.text: 1. Play the clip in the Preview window

docs.title: Refine the Transition
docs.text:
1. Repeat adjustments as needed
  2. Try different transition types if unsatisfied

Success

You have successfully added transitions to your video! You can move on to the next section.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
Issue Description Solution Crashes on Launch Software fails to open or crashes immediately. Update GPU drivers and verify system requirements. Unsupported Media Files appear grayed out during import. Ensure format is supported or re-encode files. Playback Lag Video stutters during scrubbing. Enable Proxy Mode or lower playback resolution. Missing Effects Transitions/effects don't apply. Align clips properly and verify GPU acceleration. Render Failures Export stops unexpectedly. Check disk space or try using diffrent settings or presets. Audio Sync Drift Audio desynchronizes over time. Use Audio Sync or manually align waveforms. Workspace Missing Can't find Fusion/Fairlight tabs. Switch workspace or reset UI layout.

Pro Tip

For unresolved issues, visit the official support page.
